results.headline: A Life and a Nation, Tightly Bound

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lady

results.summary_short: “The Lady” by Luc Besson is a biopic about Daw Aung San Suu Kyi of Myanmar.

results.headline: A Quiet File Clerk at the Epicenter of Political Turmoil

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Post Mortem

results.summary_short: Pablo Larraín’s “Post Mortem” observes the political turmoil in Chile, from the perspective of a morgue worker, after the 1973 military coup that overthrew the Allende government.

results.headline: Jean-Claude Van Damme, Their Hero

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Your Brother. Remember?

results.summary_short: “Your Brother. Remember?,” a good-humored exploration of brotherly bonds, is Zachary Oberzan’s latest DIY foray into pop culture.

results.headline: Stalking the Most Elusive Prey in Tasmania’s Wilds

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hunter

results.summary_short: A search for a creature long thought extinct is at the heart of “The Hunter,” starring Willem Dafoe.

results.headline: A Reluctant Pontiff Escapes to the Streets

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Have a Pope

results.summary_short: In “We Have a Pope”Michel Piccoli plays a newly elected pontiff who has his doubts about the position and runs off among the Roman populace.

results.headline: Message to Teenagers: There’s More to Life Than Bling

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We the Party

results.summary_short: Mario Van Peebles directs himself, his son and other family members in the high school movie “We the Party.”

results.headline: Real-Life Hijacking as Stylized Mass Entertainment

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Assault

results.summary_short: In “The Assault,” Julien Leclercq revisits the 1994 hijacking of a French plane with more style than historical context.

results.headline: When Human Advancement Backfires

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Surviving Progress

results.summary_short: The documentary “Surviving Progress” is a brief examination of civilization, its history and self-made discontents.

results.headline: On One Corner of America, the Violent Realities of Thug Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Player Hating: A Love Story

results.summary_short: In “Player Hating,” Maggie Hadleigh-West explores thug life in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, through the eyes of an aspiring hip-hop artist.

results.headline: Hidden Mission of Japanese-Americans in World War II

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of MIS: Human Secret Weapon

results.summary_short: “MIS: Human Secret Weapon” shines a light on the Japanese-American soldiers who worked for the Army’s Military Intelligence Service during World War II.

results.headline: A Gangster Named Ulysses Goes Home and Homeric

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Keyhole

results.summary_short: In “Keyhole” a gangster named Ulysses, played by Jason Patric, returns to a home that is haunted by regret and threatened by the prospect of revenge.

results.headline: Getting Cash and More Than They Bargained For

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of ATM

results.summary_short: Three financiers are menaced in “ATM,” the debut feature from David Brooks.

results.headline: Violet, Lily and Other Flowers of Youth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Damsels In Distress

results.summary_short: Whit Stillman’s “Damsels in Distress” examines the manners and morals of fledgling members of the privileged class at a fictional college.

results.headline: Grown Up and Married, Certainly, but Mature? Not by a Long Shot

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Reunion

results.summary_short: Jason Biggs, Seann William Scott and Eugene Levy return for the fourth installment of the “American Pie” franchise.

results.headline: The Child of a Lost War Who Gave Comics an R Rating

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tatsumi

results.summary_short: Eric Khoo’s documentary looks at how Yoshihiro Tatsumi made Japanese comics darker and more sophisticated.

results.headline: She Lets Her Sexuality Loose, and the Phone Bills Mount

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Turn Me On Dammit!

results.summary_short: In “Turn Me On, Dammit!” a hormone-addled teenager longs to escape her tiny Norwegian village.

results.headline: Telling Scary Stories and Then Living Them

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Intruders

results.summary_short: In “Intruders,” Juan Carlos Fresnadillo’s horror film starring Clive Owen, the chills come from a ghoul, Hollow Face, and from directorial sleights of hand.

results.headline: Behind Every Harassed Child? A Whole Lot of Clueless Adults

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bully

results.summary_short: Lee Hirsch’s documentary “Bully” arrives at a moment when bullying is being redefined as a social problem.

results.headline: Fisherman Off to a Mission in the Underworld

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wrath of the Titans

results.summary_short: In this sequel to the 2010 “Clash of the Titans” remake, Zeus asks his demigod son for help, as the battle for supremacy between the gods and the Titans goes on.

results.headline: A Death, a Conviction, and a Disputed Confession

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Scenes of a Crime

results.summary_short: “Scenes of a Crime,” a documentary, explores modern police interrogation methods, specifically the Reid Technique, whose goal is to extract a confession using sophisticated psychological manipulation.
